column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0114]The heated membrane may, in one embodiment, be pressed against the label on the article or container by a walking beam having a heated bladder.

#Text=Referring to FIG. 8, the walking beam 80 includes a containment box 82a, 82b on each of its longitudinal members 81a, 81b, the containment box having a flexible and conformable membrane 83a, 83b at its inner surface to create a bladder 87a, 87b.
#Text=The heated membrane 83a, 83b is positioned onto the passing labeled container 85 via a walking beam mechanism, with the container 85 in a horizontal or vertical position.
#Text=The membrane may be constructed of a conformable, high temperature, non-porous high-release material.
#Text=The bladder 87a, 87b is filled with a heated liquid or gas so as to heat the membrane 83a, 83b.
#Text=The heat from the membrane 83a, 83b is transferred to the label 86 on the container 85.
#Text=A label may be applied to one or both sides of the container.
#Text=For the sake of simplicity, a label is applied to only one surface of the container in FIG. 8

#Text=[0115]In this method, the label 86 is first applied to a center section of the container 85 with a standard peel tip dispensing process (not shown) with leading and trailing edges not tacked down.
#Text=The labeled container 85 is moved into the walking beam station 80 via a conveyor 84 and the walking beam closes in on one or more containers 85.

#Text=Pressure from the heated, expanded bladder 87a is applied to the label 86 on the container 85 at an initial contact point in the center of the label in an outward direction to the edges of the label, pushing any air under the label from the center of the label to the outer edges of the label.
#Text=The bladder is pre-heated to a target temperature based on the line speed and label material used.
#Text=The heat from the bladder membrane 83a softens the label 86 and shrinks the label.

#Text=The simultaneous application of heat and pressure from the bladder membrane 83a to the label forces the label to conform to the surface of the container 85, including the compound curve(s) of the container.
#Text=An optional subsequent heating step may be used to further shrink the label.
#Text=An advantage of this method is that labels may be applied to a wide variety of container shapes without the need for retooling.
#Text=In addition, high speed processing is possible due to the continuous heat recovery of the bladder.
#Text=[0116]FIGS. 9A and 9B illustrate another embodiment of the invention wherein a walking beam with a heated cavity is used to apply the label to the article or container.
#Text=For illustration purposes, only one side of the walking beam conveyor is shown.
#Text=The walking beam containment box 90 includes an internally heated bottle-shaped cavity 91.
#Text=The shape of the cavity 91 is configured to correspond to the container or article 92 to which the label 93 is applied.
#Text=The cavity is preheated to a target temperature based on the line speed and label material selected.
#Text=The heated cavity is positioned onto the passing labeled container via a walking beam conveyor.
#Text=The walking beam may contain a single or multiple cavities for applying heat and pressure to a single or multiple containers.
#Text=The labeled surface of the container 92 faces the interior of the cavity 91.
#Text=The interior of the cavity 91 may be lined with a conformable, soft material such as a silicon rubber sheet having imbedded electric heater wires vulcanized in place.
#Text=Heat and pressure from the cavity 91 softens the label 93 and shrinks the label.
#Text=Pressure applied by the soft cavity forces air from under the label to the edges of the label to eliminate bubbles.

#Text=The simultaneous application of heat and pressure from the heated cavity to the label 93 forces the label to conform to the surface of the container, including the compound curve(s) of the container.
#Text=The excess label material, i.e., darts and wrinkles, are eliminated by the shrinkage of the label.
#Text=An optional subsequent heating step may be used to further shrink the label.
#Text=The advantage of this method is that the exact shape of the cavity provides full bottle contact to enable rapid heat transfer and fill pressure to force air out from under the label.
#Text=[0117]FIG. 10 illustrates another embodiment of the invention for applying labels to a container having compound curves.
#Text=In this embodiment, a walking beam containment box 100 includes an internally heated soft, flexible pad 101 suspended between at least two frame members 102 as its contact surface.
#Text=For illustration purposes, only one side of the walking beam conveyor is shown.
#Text=The heated pad 101 is positioned onto the passing labeled containers via a walking beam conveyor in either the vertical or horizontal direction.
#Text=The label 104 is first applied to a contact point on the container with a standard peel tip dispensing process (not shown) with the leading and trailing edges of the label not tacked down.
#Text=The container 103 with the label adhered thereto is moved into the walking beam station via a conveyor and the walking beam moves inward to enclose the container.
#Text=The heated, flexible pad 101 is positioned to push the label 104 toward the container while removing air from under the label.
#Text=The pad 101 is pre-heated to a target temperature based on the line speed and label material selected.
#Text=The heated pad may be porous or non-porous.

#Text=The simultaneous application of heat and pressure from the heated pad 101 to the label 104 forces the label to conform to the surface of the container, including the compound curve(s) of the container.
#Text=The heat source may be one or more of radiant electric, IR electric, forced hot air and electric resistance heat integrated with the heated pad.
#Text=An optional subsequent heating step may be used to further shrink the label.
#Text=An advantage of this method includes the ability to apply labels to a wide variety of container shapes without the need for retooling.

#Text=[0118]FIGS. 11A and 11B illustrate another embodiment of the invention wherein a walking beam conveyor includes a rectangular framed containment box 110 having a flexible heated membrane mounted to the rectangular frame.
#Text=In this embodiment, an extensible, internally heated membrane 111, such as a silicone rubber sheet, is mounted over an open rectangular frame 112 along each side of a walking beam conveyor.
#Text=For illustration purposes, only one side of the walking beam conveyor is shown.
#Text=A label may be applied to one or both sides of the container 113.
#Text=The label 114 is first applied to a contact point on the container with a standard peel tip dispensing process (not shown) with the leading and trailing edges of the label not tacked down.
#Text=The membrane 111 is mounted so that tension is applied across the membrane.
#Text=The perimeter dimensions of the rectangular frame 111 are larger than the overall profile of the container 113 to be labeled.
#Text=In one embodiment, the depth of the frame is greater than one-half the thickness of the container to be labeled to allow the container to penetrate the plane of the membrane.

#Text=The open/close motion of the walking beam provides sufficient force to trap the container 113 between a supported membrane 111 on each side of the walking beam, or one side of the walking beam, to force the container 113 into the frame 112 while the heated membrane 111 conforms to the surface of the container 113.
#Text=The membrane is pre-heated to a target temperature based on the line speed and label material selected.
#Text=The dwell time of the closed walking beam can be controlled through the walking beam station by the design of the cam system.
#Text=The walking beam may contain a plurality of rectangular frames to apply labels to a plurality of containers.

#Text=As the walking beam opens and reciprocates, the labeled container may optionally be enclosed within the membranes of the walking beam a second time for a second application of heat and pressure.

#Text=The simultaneous application of heat and pressure from the membrane 111 to the label 114 forces the label to conform to the surface of the container 113, including the compound curve(s) of the container.
#Text=An optional subsequent heating step may be used to further shrink the label 114.
#Text=The advantage of this embodiment is that the generic shape of the rectangular frame allows containers having various shapes to be labeled without the necessity of providing unique frames.
